Tyrannosaurus: Tyrannosaurus rex was one of the largest land predators ever known. It lived during the late Cretaceous period and could grow up to 40 feet long!
Triceratops: Triceratops was a large herbivorous dinosaur with three distinctive horns and a large bony frill. It lived during the late Cretaceous period.
Stegosaurus: Stegosaurus was a large, heavily built dinosaur with distinctive plates along its back and spikes on its tail for defense.
Velociraptor: Despite popular media portrayals, Velociraptors were actually about the size of a large turkey, but they were incredibly intelligent pack hunters.
Brontosaurus: Brontosaurus was a long-necked sauropod dinosaur that lived during the late Jurassic period. It could grow up to 72 feet long!
Allosaurus: Allosaurus was a large theropod dinosaur that lived during the late Jurassic period. It was a fearsome predator with powerful jaws and sharp teeth.
Diplodocus: Diplodocus was one of the longest dinosaurs ever discovered, with some specimens reaching over 90 feet in length.
Parasaurolophus: Parasaurolophus was a duck-billed dinosaur known for its distinctive hollow crest, which it used to make loud honking sounds.
Ankylosaurus: Ankylosaurus was heavily armored with bony plates and spikes, and had a massive club at the end of its tail for defense.
Spinosaurus: Spinosaurus was a massive semi-aquatic dinosaur with a distinctive sail on its back and crocodile-like snout for catching fish.
Carnotaurus: Carnotaurus was a fast-running predator with distinctive horns above its eyes and tiny, almost useless arms.
Iguanodon: Iguanodon was one of the first dinosaurs ever discovered and was a large herbivore with distinctive thumb spikes.
Compsognathus: Compsognathus was one of the smallest known dinosaurs, about the size of a chicken, and was a swift predator.
Archaeopteryx: Archaeopteryx is considered the missing link between dinosaurs and birds, with both feathers and teeth.
Giganotosaurus: Giganotosaurus was one of the largest land predators ever, potentially even larger than T-rex.
